An old server encrypted its flag with RSA, but used two Blum integers to generate its key. Can you decrypt the message? Ciphertext: 3648512036481893323326266566100006985326561522707980143415721508524218832830043315255591226143287724873761696529570724652550493056120292388619577763923539

The flag format is flag{...}
n=9754487109397926127239724129435014344814983881790194913696300638528091474024967431568149881618583434157286098240384690008751420135102110230010577254720693, e=5752098313930614960700164681948075497907490221427266816316671395851884625469653517883176530615122425320550051231581290705446589729900557187802085892364429
The lower 104 bits of p are: 71373062505162340998072348455392328003


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{ar6yrwyj}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 3648512036481893323326266566100006985326561522707980143415721508524218832830043315255591226143287724873761696529570724652550493056120292388619577763923539
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=9754487109397926127239724129435014344814983881790194913696300638528091474024967431568149881618583434157286098240384690008751420135102110230010577254720693, e=5752098313930614960700164681948075497907490221427266816316671395851884625469653517883176530615122425320550051231581290705446589729900557187802085892364429
The lower 104 bits of p are: 71373062505162340998072348455392328003

extra_info: p=85194182581281203971391460796724311347508244904203008307220671974871642487107, q=114497103133673050190935285178944579193962024459185081321036520708294209695399, Ï†(n)=9754487109397926127239724129435014344814983881790194913696300638528091474024767740282434927364421107411310429349843219739388032045473853037327411402538188
